1e:T5b8,{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"FAQPage","mainEntity":[{"@type":"Question","name":"Do Italian citizens need a visa for Argentina?","acceptedAnswer":{"@type":"Answer","text":"No visa required for 90 days. Italian citizens can enter with passport and apply for residency under bilateral agreements."}},{"@type":"Question","name":"How Italian is Argentina really?","acceptedAnswer":{"@type":"Answer","text":"Extremely. Over 60% of Argentines have Italian ancestry. Buenos Aires has a 'Little Italy,' Italian is the second most spoken language in homes, and Italian culture permeates food, language, and customs."}},{"@type":"Question","name":"Will I need to speak Spanish?","acceptedAnswer":{"@type":"Answer","text":"Yes, though you'll find many Italians here and Italian is widely understood. Argentine Spanish has significant Italian influence (Lunfardo), making it easier for Italians to learn."}},{"@type":"Question","name":"Are Italian professional qualifications recognized?","acceptedAnswer":{"@type":"Answer","text":"Generally yes, especially for culinary arts, design, fashion, and engineering. Some professions may require validation depending on regulatory requirements."}},{"@type":"Question","name":"Is there an Italian business community?","acceptedAnswer":{"@type":"Answer","text":"Yes, very active. The Italian Chamber of Commerce, Italian restaurants, importers, and Italian-Argentine businesses create strong networking
